PARACELSUS.

PARACELSUS is a fortunate man3 his enemies were his first biographers. By their exertions he has had every one of his faults‚ every one of his delinquencie5‚ every one of his sins and shortcomings carefully portrayed‚ minutely‚ almost lovingly described, unweariedly repeated. While it is no use, therefore, for any subsequent historian to try to make him out worse than he has been already depicted‚ an opportunity is thereby afforded to those who, whether actuated by charity and wholesome scepticism to believe him not so bad as has been said, or by perversity to think differently from the mass, or by curiosity to examine the statement5‚ the inferences, and the credibility of the authorities, might be inclined to represent him as better. Compared with those who repeat with indifference what is detrimental to Paracelsus, the charitable and doubtful, the perverse and curious are, it is true, in a minority; nor is it difficult to see why. It is, generally speaking, easier to copy what has been said before than to say something new; it is less troublesome to reiterate statements than to examine patiently the grounds on which they rest; brilliant sarcasm and crushing invective, hard names and
